pros: It was very very fun
cons: it was a lot of work

pros: Great faculty and freedom to teach
cons: The quality of students could be better.

pros: The student body is extraordinary with individuals hungry to learn more. They are extremely respectful and you probably wont be able to find students better than them. Fellow employees are great at what they do and up lifting.
cons: Communication across departments is struggling. Difficulty with curriculum strength. Alot of request from admin to change curriculum outline on a consistent basis. Salary.

pros: Flexible Schedule, Great Benefits, Great Management, Good Work Culture, Great Educational Environment.
cons: I have no complaints about the work environment.

pros: Great support staff that always have your back.
cons: Paperwork overload! Tons of forms to fill out.

pros: Great Place to Work and it is so much better than other chiropractic colleges
cons: I can't think of any cons with the place. The culture is great.

review_title: Parker University is the best workplace with a caring culture and commitment to higher education
pros:
Parker University has a great, caring team with champions from the President, the Deans, and inspiring leaders to the empowerment of every team member. They are devoted to wellness and higher education, inspiring our future graduates and faculty to strive for excellence.

In addition to great benefits and an excellent faculty course load, they care about every student and are devoted to growing new programs, caring about their team, and nurturing the community.

The employee benefits are great, the President's letters during the tornado and pandemic were inspirational, the Dean is committed to students and faculty success, and our team is devoted and support each other. HR is great and the IT organization is amazing. They respond fast, send out entertaining scam education to protect the team, and scheduled great training programs that were the best I've seen in over 25 years in education.

It is a joy to receive email messages that are caring and compassionate in the face of great strife.
cons: I've worked for Parker University for two years and have not discovered any cons. It is a pleasure to work at Parker University with a dedicated and caring faculty, staff, and leadership.

review_title: A rapidly growing university that is centered around loving service.
job_title: Director of Research in Dallas, TX
pros: Small enough to care, large enough to make a difference.
cons: Growing - thus still working on kinks that occur through this process.

pros: Work and home balance, Good salary, and Nice retirement.
cons: Mostly care about Chiropractic program

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in Irving, TX
pros: You will be treated like a human being.
cons: Everything is constantly changing and exapnding

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Dallas, TX
pros: I can't name any pros of working at this company. Possible that the staff are nice, but the workload for the pay is ridiculous
cons: Lack of training, non-responsive, students always unhappy with the department.

pros: Everyone is really passionate about their position and ready to help. The community takes their health serious.
cons: not really cons but there's a lack of structure.

pros: The faculty was like a family.
cons: No long summer vacation - 3 trimesters a year

pros: Nice facilities to work in and work out in
cons: Bad area / poor part of town

review_title: Parker University cares for students and faculty
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: I am very proud to work at Parker University and recommend it highly. I've taught for six terms at Parker University and over 20 years at other schools. I am fortunate to work with an amazing team. It is a blessing to work with people of good character who work so hard to provide quality education. They nurture team relationships, share guidance in a thoughtful, caring manner, and provide quality tools for working online. They host conferences, technology training sessions for faculty to adapt during the pandemic, and think of the Parker community as a unified culture. I am delighted to teach and work for an excellent department chair and a CEO who write thoughtful, caring messages to support our campus and our culture of support. In addition, they invite faculty to participate in offering suggestions for a five-year vision, which is a great way to work for a future together.
cons: I have no employment cons nor have I observed any.

review_title: Parker University is not a great place to work
pros:
- PTO is very generous, but it seems they were reducing it when I left. Used to get over two weeks during the holidays and now they brag about giving you one week. Really it is three extra days since most companies give you Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. Not much to brag about anymore.
- You will probably work with a couple of nice folks at some point.
cons:
- Glass ceiling.
- Scary location.
- High turnover (some by choice, other not by choice). 
- Always new people trying to change everything (systems, processes, etc.) and the rest of the teams have to pick up the pieces when they leave. Those were put in place for a reason. Maybe you should listen and find out why before you cause more disruption. Yes, you know who you are!
- Very much into chiropractic and all decisions are made from a chiropractic perspective instead of a strategic business plan.
- Their initials are PU.

review_title: Very flexible work environment but NO diversity in leadership
pros: The work-life balance is exceptional at Parker since they allow their employees to work from home and are very generous with vacation time. There are plenty of opportunities to work with various projects and learn new technology.
cons: The managerial staff and board could use some diversification to make it a fair place to grow if you're not white. The school location is not in the most healthies of environments since its sitting in the middle of a red-light district.

review_title: A university with a committment to making the world a better place!
pros: Parker University is dedicated to becoming a comprehensive university, and most employees truly believe in the mission to be a leader in health and wellness. Parker promotes a strong work-life balance and supports professional development. Faculty, staff and administration care about the well-being of students and each other. Some reviews state Parker is not a loving place anymore, but it is more loving than many companies I know of.
cons: Growth is challenging, and Parker is experiencing growing pains. Most employees want Parker to remain a strong health and wellness institution in Dallas, but some employees do not understand what growth takes and actually impede expansion. One Parker Principle, however, states "Do not let the negative few overrule the positive many."

pros: Great vacation benefits. Ok to Nice office space. Beautiful campus.
cons: Expensive and poor health insurance; prices going up up up, and value going down. Spouse not covered if they may take insurance from their employer. Vision insurance practically non-existent. Dental so limited as to be of little value.

pros:
Great people supporting the school.  Top management is highly skilled.  Faculty and staff are very dedicated and hard working.  New President is a very good person with passion for the profession.
Many students are fired up for chiropractic and love the school.
cons:
Many long term faculty feeling that the school has lost its identity and family feeling. There is a disconnect among top management, faculty and students.  The "love concept" that the school was built on has gone from the campus.  Many good people have jumped ship recently. 
  Some strange challenges to get simple requests for essential materials are too frequent among several departments.

review_title: Great People, but hard to grow
pros:
Great people, with a good fun family atmosphere.  You will never work with a closer knit bunch of people, or at least that's how it was in my department.  

Multiple hats, fun students, free adjustments.
cons:
The company is always going through change, and while some of it is good, it's not always communicated well to the people in the field.  

Also, because it is small there is not much room for growth.  

The area of town it is in is a bit seedy too, but I suppose if you like strip clubs this might be a place for you.

review_title: Great place but not much room for advancement
pros: GREAT people and benefits!  Students are friendly and interested in health and wellness.   Faculty and staff have good relationships with and respect each other
cons: I mostly feel safe on campus, but the neighborhood is getting worse each year.

pros: The students are wonderful and the campus is small and has a community feel. The university is growing so there are a lot of areas in which to develop new skills.
cons: The employees are treated poorly by administration. Most employees work multiple roles for very little pay and as soon as you have a difference of opinion with an administrator you are fired. Hard work and loyalty are not valued here.

pros: The work life balance is excellent.  There is a very generous PTO policy in addition to a week off for the holidays.  It's a family oriented culture. The benefits are very rich.  There is a flat 6% employer contribution to your retirement if you contribute at least 1% of your salary!
cons:
There has been President turnover.  This can cause some morale issues as people get worried about changes in leadership goals and vision.  However, I believe we are on the upswing and am looking forward to the future.  

Sometimes the work pace is slower in an Academic environment as opposed to corporate.  That can take some getting used to.

review_title: True to its core values of overall excellence,  service to others, health and well-being
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Dallas, TX
pros:
- Helpful and compassionate group of faculty and staff
- Tons of preventative health care opportunities (clinic on site with free care, good health insurance benefits, funds to use for gym/fitness classes, quarterly health challenges with great prizes)
- Good holiday breaks for time with loved ones
- Two on site gyms and a sauna (Use as needed/able to! there are also complimentary fitness classes)
- Beautiful campus
cons: Things can get lost in translation at times if  you do not pay attention to emailed announcements. Stay up on your emails and it's not an issue! :)

job_title: Director of Admissions in Dallas, TX
pros: Parker University was a great place to work. The atmosphere was super, very positive, and we were encouraged to grow and give our best to the school.
cons: I found the school to be a very positive experience and do not have any major complaints about Parker. They are on the grow and employees are encouraged to set goals and be the best they can be.

pros: Parker is a health and wellness institution so the vibe on campus is always great.  Our faculty, staff and students go out of their way to be helpful and welcoming.  The administration is supportive of employees development.  We enjoy excellent benefits and great work life balance.
cons: We are growing and moving very quickly.  Sometimes communication is lacking.

pros: Paid time off for Christmas
cons: Not paid enough based on my title or experience

review_title: Used to be Great, Now a Regular University
pros: The benefits have been awesome for years. Very friendly and family oriented culture.
cons: Even though they are still better than most educational environments and way better than corporate America, they are cutting benefits. New administration is very command and control, not collaborate, not innovative, not modern in management.

review_title: I can't believe it's still going on
pros: Vacation time and holidays off are great. You can travel to seminars through the company even though we mainly go play and hang out with each other.
cons:
The people at the top are pretty ignorant and for the most  part greatly uneducated. Promotions depend on how much you kiss up to these so called leaders or through good old fashioned nepotism. 
Rotten from HR on down.
Covering up for prejudice practices. 
Cheap products.

pros: The benefits at Parker University are exceptional.  I enjoy the attitude of "Loving Service" which one of the Values of the university.  There is very much a team/collaboration feel.
cons: Want more people to know about us.  We are in growth mode.

pros: The students are wonderful and are hungry to learn!
cons:
Severely under compensated while administrators are compensated above average.  Look at the salary data on the Chronicle of Higher education to see just how low Parker University professors are paid based on their rank compared to the National average.

It is run more like the trade school than a first professional degree school.  The administrators are very sensitive to criticism.  Overall, Parker lacks talented professors and is is not a wonder.

review_title: Not a place you'd want to work
pros: I met some really nice, helpful people there.
cons: Management and board are confused about whether the university should be comprehensive or whether they just want to be a chiropractic college. The CFO keeps threatening to shut programs down for non-performance even though the university hasn't spent a nickel to promote them. They claim to care about people, but have an odd way of showing it, proven by the number of good, dedicated people who have left.

review_title: Parker talks the talk, and walks the walk.
pros:
Full acceptance and tolerant of all students, staff, and patients.
Truly living and loving the shared experience of health and wellness.
Caring environment that recognizes the integrity and service of its employees.
cons:
Communication between departments 
Limited parking for patients

pros: Small friendly people that care about the DC students
cons: CEO is all about himself as he speaks one way and acts behind the scenes in a way to only promote himself.  He hires and places friends in leadership roles and trustee positions.

review_title: Parker University is a great place to work
pros: Family atmosphere, employee benefits, opportunities for growth and development, friendly environment, happy culture, ability to serve on several committees
cons: Location of the university could be better- not much close by in regards to lunch options

review_title: Some departments are great... others not so much.
job_title: Insurance and Scheduling Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Amazing health benefits. Vacation and personal time are pretty excellent as well.
cons: Departments are very isolated from each other. Which leads to quite a bit of tension when having to work with other departments. There's a bit of an us vs. them mentality.

pros: Friendly co-workers. Good Benefits, good work life balance
cons: Poor Managment, inability to make common sense decisions. VP Business Office calling all the shots.

pros: Many changes over the last five years.  Rebranding and struggling to gain market share.
cons: Due to poor management from the previous administration, the new administration micro-manage the department leaders.

pros: The people, the family feel of the campus, administration takes great care of its faculty and staff, plus some added perks for employees.
cons: No negatives, in my opinion.

pros: Loving, Diverse, Innovative institution; visionary and decisive leadership; great benefits and perks, state of the art classrooms.
cons: Some neighborhood challenges...but continue to address.

pros: 2 weeks off at Christmas
cons: Glass ceiling. If you aren't a white chiropractic man you are limited.

job_title: Assistant Director of Financial Aid in Plano, TX
pros: Some great people are in certain departments.
cons: Newer senior management is greedy, and the culture of this sweet school was demolished. Constant change in this workplace.

review_title: Overall, Parker University is a good place to work.
pros: Most departments work well together.
cons: Currently undergoing changes and growth, the communication level between departments and management needs improvement.

pros: Getting experience as doctor in clinical setting.
cons: School is very money hungry

pros: To gain experience with some of the best doctors in the profession.
cons: If you don't meet your patient recruitment requirement then you will have to repeat a trimester.

pros: Professional, friendly environment, staff are helpful
cons: The drive is 23 miles from home

job_title: Director of Marketing in Dallas, TX
pros: Awesome team spirit, great benefits, leadership is outstanding
cons: There are no cons that aren't experienced in any normal work environment

pros: Some staff members in some departments
cons: incompetent management is running the new programs that is why they are not getting the " numbers of the students" they want.

pros: Great work environment all around
cons: No room to move up

cons: Dallas traffic! maybe more substantial raises

pros: Academic atmosphere, with mostly 25-40 year old students (career change)
cons: Political, pay, environment, benefits, slow growth

pros: Friendly Atmosphere, Family Oriented, and Love

review_title: I read the reviews and thought I could make a difference
pros: Opportunity to do everything and not be properly compensated
cons: No compensation for those opportunities
